title: Building and Securing a Small Network
description: Network design principles, redundancy, troubleshooting, and baseline establishment

keyConcepts.title: Network Redundancy
keyConcepts.description: Designing networks with multiple paths between devices to eliminate single points of failure. Uses physically separate cabled paths to ensure continued operation if one link or device fails.

keyConcepts.title: Network Baseline
keyConcepts.description: Documentation of expected network performance under normal conditions. Includes bandwidth usage, response times, and traffic patterns. Used to identify performance degradation and capacity planning.

keyConcepts.title: Protocol Analyzer
keyConcepts.description: Tool used to capture and analyze network traffic. Documents traffic requirements on each segment to determine needs for network growth and identify performance issues.

keyConcepts.title: Real-Time Applications
keyConcepts.description: Services like voice and video that are sensitive to delay and require Quality of Service (QoS) considerations. Cannot tolerate high latency or packet loss.

keyConcepts.title: Structured Troubleshooting Approach
keyConcepts.description: Systematic method: (1) Identify the problem, (2) Establish theory of probable causes, (3) Test the theory, (4) Establish plan of action, (5) Implement solution, (6) Verify functionality, (7) Document.

keyConcepts.title: Network Documentation
keyConcepts.description: Essential for maintaining and troubleshooting networks. Includes topology diagrams, IP addressing schemes, baseline performance data, and configuration backups.

importantPoints: Redundancy eliminates single points of failure using multiple paths
Baseline establishes normal network performance metrics
Protocol analyzers document traffic patterns for capacity planning
Voice and video are real-time applications sensitive to delay
Increased ping response times indicate latency issues
DHCP automatically assigns IP addresses on networks
show ip route displays routing table and exit interfaces
show ip interface brief shows interface IPs and up/down status
show interfaces provides detailed duplex, speed, and error info
show running-config displays active device configuration
show cdp neighbors detail reveals neighbor IP, hostname, IOS version
show cdp neighbors verifies Layer 2 connectivity between devices
ping tests end-to-end connectivity and measures round-trip time
tracert/traceroute identifies each hop and where packets are lost
Extended ping allows specifying source interface
Ping symbols: ! = success, . = timeout, U = unreachable
169.254.x.x indicates PC cannot reach DHCP server (APIPA)
nslookup verifies DNS name resolution
terminal monitor enables debug messages on remote sessions
ipconfig displays Windows PC network information
ipconfig getifaddr [interface] shows Mac interface IP
Structured approach starts with identifying problem, ends with documentation
